January 25, 1987: Fiction
RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear
weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III.
IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a
woman who grew up in a small Maine town.
WHIRLWIND, by James Clavell. (Morrow, $22.95.) Iran during the month following
the Shah's departure.
BANDITS, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House, $17.95.) A gang of three plots to
heist millions being sent to the contras in Nicaragua.
THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex
family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City.
A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $18.95.) Inspector Adam
Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder.
FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts. (Naval Institute, $15.95.) Navy
aviators at war over Vietnam.
NIGHT OF THE FOX, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A mission to
keep D-Day plans from being discovered by the Germans.
HOLLYWOOD HUSBANDS, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A top
model encounters three of Los Angeles's most dynamic men.
FOUNDATION AND EARTH, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday,  $16.95.) The hero of
the ''Foundation'' series searches for the lost planet Earth.
WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A rich orphan comes of
age while she travels the world.
THE COUNTERLIFE, by Philip Roth. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux,  $18.95.) More
about the ambitions and anxieties of Nathan Zuckerman, who resembles he
author in some things, sometimes.
THE PANIC OF '89, by Paul Erdman. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A financial wizard
undertakes to defuse the crisis besetting Wall Street and the American economy.
THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. (Random House, $19.95.)
Romance, family conflict, power and greed mark a young woman's life in 18th
century England and France.
DEATH QUEST, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $18.95.) A hit man sets
out to kill Countess Krak and seal the fate of the Earth; sixth volume in the
''Mission Earth'' series.
January 25, 1987
Non-Fiction
FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and
ruminations from the television star and father of five.
A SEASON ON THE BRINK, by John Feinstein. (Macmillan, $16.95.) A chronicle
of one season spent with the coach Bob Knight and his Indiana University
basketball team.
A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on
May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists.
HIS WAY, by Kitty Kelley. (Bantam, $21.95.) An unauthorized biography of Frank
Sinatra.
THE SEARCH FOR SIGNS OF INTELLIGENT LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE, by Jane
Wagner. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Acerb observations on life today; script of the
show starring Lily Tomlin.
MCMAHON! by Jim McMahon with Bob Verdi. (Warner, $16.95.) The
autobiography of the quarterback for the Chicago Bears.
YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at
the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme.
WORD FOR WORD, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Putnam, $16.95.) A new collection of
columns by the journalist and television personality.
JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.)
Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal.
DANCING ON MY GRAVE, by Gelsey Kirkland with Greg Lawrence. (Doubleday,
$17.95.) The ballerina recalls her checkered career.
ACROSS CHINA, by Peter Jenkins. (Morrow, $18.95.) The author of ''A Walk
Across America'' takes his wanderlust to Asia.
THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $19.95.) The crisis in the
American automobile industry and Japan's role in it.
MARILYN, by Gloria Steinem. (Holt, $24.95.) A biography of Marilyn Monroe, with
many photographs by her friend George Barris.
ONE KNEE EQUALS TWO FEET, by John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Villard,
$16.95.) Observations on football.
NECESSARY  LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a
series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow.
